title: Why Huawei's AI Chip Failed to Power DeepSeek's R2 Model - Inside the
text:
DeepSeek’s much-anticipated R2 AI model was supposed to arrive in May, ready to challenge industry giants. Instead, it’s stuck in limbo because, reportedly, there were issues that forced the delay.
Training bottlenecks with Huawei’s Ascend chip have thrown the schedule off track and raised bigger questions about whether China’s AI ambitions can outrun its hardware limits. DeepSeek needs this update, and they need it badly; that’s why we can see some big updates coming soon.

After launching R1 in January, Chinese authorities nudged the company to ditch Nvidia chips in favour of homegrown Huawei hardware. The idea looked brilliant on paper, cutting ties with U.S. tech and boosting self-reliance. In practice, it’s been a grind of technical glitches and delays.
Huawei’s Ascend processors were supposed to be DeepSeek’s ticket to independence from U.S. tech. Instead, they became the biggest obstacle in training its R2 model. During the training phase, the chips struggled with performance bottlenecks and compatibility glitches, derailing every attempt at a full-scale run. The setback forced DeepSeek to return to Nvidia GPUs for training, relegating Huawei’s hardware to lighter inference tasks.
Huawei didn’t just watch from the sidelines. Its engineers flew in to work alongside DeepSeek’s team, tweaking systems and running diagnostics. But even with their expertise, the setup never achieved a stable training session. The mission now is to make Ascend chips reliable for inference, though that journey is still far from over.
The real winners in AI will be the teams that share strategic independence along with technical excellence, ensuring that chip choice accelerates, rather than hinders, progress. For developers, the message is clear: in the race to build smarter AI, the smartest move might be picking the right silicon from the start.
